title: Layup
description: A layup is a fundamental and common inside shot where a player drives towards the basket and releases the ball near the hoop with one hand.

title: Finger Roll
description: Similar to a layup, the finger roll is a soft, high-arcing shot where the player uses their fingertips to release the ball gently into the basket.

title: Hook Shot
description: A hook shot involves a one-handed shot with a sweeping, hooking motion of the arm. It is often used by post players close to the basket.

title: Jump Hook
description: Similar to a hook shot, the jump hook involves a player jumping while executing the hook shot. This adds elevation to the shot and helps avoid defenders.

title: Baby Hook
description: A shorter version of the hook shot, typically used when a player is very close to the basket.

title: Drop Step
description: A post move where a player, after receiving the ball in the post, makes a quick step towards the baseline to create separation from the defender and takes a close-range shot.

title: Up-and-Under
description: A move in which a player fakes a shot in one direction, gets the defender to jump, and then quickly moves under the defender to take a shot on the other side.

title: Power Move
description: Involves using physical strength to back down an opponent and take a close-range shot or layup.

title: Spin Move
description: A player uses a spin move to create space and take a shot close to the basket, often after driving towards the hoop.

title: Floaters
description: While not directly under the basket, floaters are shots taken within the key area but farther away, involving a soft touch to get the ball over defenders.

title: Reverse Layup
description: A layup where a player approaches the basket from one side and releases the ball on the opposite side, often used to avoid shot-blockers.

title: Pull-up Jumper
description: A player dribbles towards the basket and stops quickly, pulling up for a jump shot before the defense can react. This is often effective for guards who can change pace and direction.

title: Fadeaway Shot
description: Similar to a jump shot, a fadeaway involves leaning backward while shooting, creating separation from the defender. Post players often use this shot to shoot over defenders.

title: Step-back Jumper
description: The player takes a step back, creating space between them and the defender before taking a jump shot. This move is popular among perimeter players who want to create separation.

title: Turnaround Jumper
description: A player catches the ball with their back to the basket, turns around, and shoots in one motion. This is often seen in the post area.

title: Bank Shot
description: Shooting the ball off the backboard at an angle to make the shot. This can be effective when a player is close to the basket but not directly in front of it.

title: Pull-up Bank Shot
description: Similar to a regular pull-up jumper, but the player aims to bank the ball off the backboard.

title: Mid-Range Floater
description: A floater shot taken from the mid-range area, typically used when a player is in motion and needs to release the ball over a defender.

title: Baseline Jumper
description: A shot taken from the side of the key along the baseline. Players may use a quick pull-up or a fadeaway from this area.

title: Elbow Jumper
description: Shots taken from the elbows of the free-throw line are common mid-range shots. Players often utilize screens or dribble moves to create space for these shots.

title: Catch-and-Shoot Mid-Range
description: Players catch a pass and quickly release a jump shot from the mid-range area. This is often seen in catch-and-shoot situations or off screens.

title: Three-Pointers
description: Three-pointers are shots taken from beyond the three-point arc, which is a specific distance from the basket. In the standard FIBA and NBA basketball court, the three-point line is situated at 6.75 meters (22 feet 1.75 inches) in the corners and 7.24 meters (23 feet 9 inches) elsewhere along the arc.

title: Catch-and-Shoot Three
description: A player receives a pass and immediately shoots the ball without dribbling. This is often facilitated by good ball movement or by drawing defenders and kicking the ball out.

title: Pull-up Three
description: A player dribbles towards the three-point line and pulls up for a shot. This move requires a quick release and is effective for guards who can change pace and direction.

title: Step-back Three
description: Similar to the mid-range step-back, this move involves a player taking a step back to create separation before shooting a three-pointer.

title: Corner Three
description: Shots taken from the corners of the court, which are the shortest distance to the three-point line. Many shooters specialize in corner threes due to the shorter distance.

title: Top-of-the-Key Three
description: Three-pointers taken from the center of the three-point line, often following a pick-and-roll or a quick perimeter pass.

title: Transition Three
description: Players take three-pointers in fast-break situations, capitalizing on a defense that hasn't set up. This requires quick decision-making and shooting accuracy.

title: Spot-up Three
description: A player positions themselves in an open spot behind the three-point line and waits for a pass to shoot without much movement.

title: Off-the-Dribble Three
description: Players create their own shot by dribbling and then pulling up for a three-pointer. This requires a combination of ball-handling and shooting skills.

title: Step-in Three
description: Similar to a pull-up, but the player takes a step forward into the shot, often used to exploit defenders who are expecting a drive.

title: Fadeaway Three
description: A challenging shot where a player fades away from the defender while shooting a three-pointer. This requires excellent balance and shooting technique.

title: Banked Three
description: Unconventional but occasionally used, a player intentionally banks the ball off the backboard to score a three-pointer.

title: Half-Court Shot
description: A long-distance shot taken from beyond the half-court line, typically attempted at the end of quarters or games. It's a low-percentage shot but can be a buzzer-beater.

title: Alley-Oop
description: A play where a player throws the ball near the basket only for a teammate to jump, catch it mid-air, and score in one motion.

title: Putback or Tip-In
description: A shot made by tipping the ball into the basket immediately after a teammate's missed shot. This is often done by players with good timing and leaping ability.

title: Hook Shot
description: While the hook shot is commonly associated with inside play, it can also be used from mid-range distances, particularly by post players facing away from the basket.

title: Pump Fake and Drive
description: A player fakes a shot to get the defender to jump, then drives past the defender for a closer shot or layup.

title: Euro Step
description: A move where a player takes a step in one direction and then quickly steps in the opposite direction to evade defenders and get to the basket.

title: Runners or Teardrops
description: Shots taken on the move, typically from mid-range, using a high release to avoid shot-blockers.

title: Reverse Layup or Dunk
description: A layup or dunk in which a player approaches the basket from one side but releases the ball on the opposite side, often used to avoid defenders.
